qas.question: What medical scientist first proposed the clonal selection theory of immunology?
What triggers an immune response according to CST?
In CST, what triggers a destructive immune response?
What property of T cells caused modification of CST?
When was clonal selection theory first proposed?

context: <a4_0>In the mid-1950s<a4_0/>, <a0_0>Frank Burnet<a0_0/>, inspired by a suggestion made by Niels Jerne, formulated the clonal selection theory (CST) of immunity. On the basis of CST, Burnet developed a theory of how an immune response is triggered according to the <a1_0>self/nonself distinction<a1_0/>: "self" constituents (constituents of the body) do not trigger destructive immune responses, while <a2_0>"nonself" entities (e.g., pathogens, an allograft)<a2_0/> trigger a destructive immune response. The theory was later modified to reflect new discoveries regarding histocompatibility or <a3_0>the complex "two-signal" activation<a3_0/> of T cells. The self/nonself theory of immunity and the self/nonself vocabulary have been criticized, but remain very influential.
